title: Lewis Capaldi, Stormzy and The 1975 win big at the Q Awards
text:
Lewis Capaldi, Stormzy and The 1975 win big at the Q Awards (Picture: Getty)

Lewis Capaldi, Stormzy and The 1975 have won big at the Q Awards.

The star-studded ceremony took place tonight, at the Roundhouse in London, and saw the likes of Foals, Kano and Biffy Clyro grace the red carpet.

But while the A-listers had fun posing up a storm in front of the cameras, they were all there to celebrate the best music produced throughout 2019.

And it seems as though Lewis will be going home a very happy man, as he managed to scoop the best track award for his number one hit, Someone You Loved.

The 1975 also took to the stage where they were presented with best act in the world today, alongside Edwyn Collins, who fetched the Maverick gong.

This year saw the longest nominations list to date, making it even more competitive for the artists to scoop their prize.

But it seems as though Mancunian band Pale Waves represented the north as Q’s best breakthrough act.

Lewis scooped best track award for his number one hit, Someone You Loved (Picture: PA)

Kano was a happy man after winning best contribution to music (Picture: PA)

The show went on to make history, as it saw the first-ever female host Nadine Shah address the crowd, which was full of music’s biggest stars.

She did a stunning job and managed to win over her fellow musicians throughout the lavish ceremony.

Stormzy also won best solo act, rounding off his incredible year nicely – especially after his Glastonbury performance this summer.

Anna Calvi scooped the Fender Play Award (Picture: PA)

Dizzee Rascal all smiles after winning the Q Innovation In Sound award (Picture: PA)

The show saw its first-ever female host Nadine Shah (Picture: Redferns)

The star owned the stage during the festival, where he became the first solo black British male artist to headline.

Following his performance, the rapper told his fans: ‘At 25 years old I am the second youngest solo act to ever headline Glastonbury, the youngest being a 24-year-old David Bowie in 1971.

‘I’m overwhelmed with emotions, this is the most surreal feeling I’ve ever experienced.’

He continued: ‘I feel my entire life has lead to this moment. Can’t explain or fathom what this all is but I am 100% sure this is all God and his favour. Giving him all the glory.

‘Thank you to Emily & Mike Eavis for believing in me I can’t wait to see you and hug you both thank you so much.’

Elsewhere on the red carpet, Pulp singer Jarvis Cocker rocked up with Extinction Rebellion protestors holding banners calling for climate change action.

Q Awards winners 2019 Q Best Breakthrough Act – Pale Waves Q Best Track – Lewis Capaldi for Someone You Loved Q Best Album – Foals for Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost (Part 1) Q Best Live Act Performance – Michael Kiwanuka for End Of The Road Festival Q Best Solo Act – Stormzy Q Best Act In The World Today – The 1975 Q Best Festival/Event– All Points East Q Innovation In Sound – Dizzie Rascal Q Classic Album – Tricky – Maxinquaye Q Maverick – Edwyn Collins Fender Play Award – Anna Calvi Q Outstanding Contribution To Music – Kano Q Classic Songwriter – Kevin Rowland Q Inspiration – Madness Q Icon – Christine And The Queens Q Hero – Kim Gordon Q Song Of The Decade – Lana Del Rey for Video Games Q Best Vocal Performance – Little Simz
